CASE SUMMARY 
 
1. The Claimant (the “ Bank ”) is a Ukrainian bank which was nationalised in December 2016. 
Prior to its nationalisation, the Bank was substantially owned by the First Defendant (“ D1”) 
and the Second Defendant (“ D2”). D1 and D2 also sat on the Bank’s Supervisory Board, 
of which D2 was Chairman from 1997 to 30 April 2015. Following its nationalisation, D1 
and D2 (and the other members of the Supervisory Board) were dismissed and replaced 
by a new management team. 
 
2. The English Defendants are Teamtrend Limited (" D3"), Trade Point Agro Limited (" D4") 
and Collyer Limited (" D5").  The BVI Defendants are Rossyn Investing Corp (" D6"), Milbert 
Ventures Inc (" D7") and ZAO UKRTransitService Limited (" D8"). 
 
3. In these proceedings, the Bank claims that D1 and D2 procured the misappropriation of 
US$1,911,877,385 from the Bank. In particular, the Bank claims that: 
a. D1 and D2 controlled all material decisions made by the Bank and caused the Bank 
to make loans to 47 Ukrainian companies and three Cypriot companies (the 
AA1/2/1
 
   
 “Borrowers ” and the “ Relevant Loans ”), which were all ultimately owned and 
controlled by D1 and D2; 
b. D1 and D2 also ultimately owned or controlled D3-8;  
c. D1 and D2 caused the Borrowers to enter into sham supply agreements with D3-8 
(the “ Relevant Supply Agreements ”), which provided for D3-8 to deliver large 
quantities of equipment and commodities, and for certain of the Borrowers to make 
‘pre-payments’ to D3-8 (i.e. to pay before the equipment or commodities had been 
delivered); and 
d. between May and August 2014, and pursuant to the Relevant Supply Agreements, 
certain of the Borrowers made pre-payments to D3-8 totalling US$1,911,877,3851, 
but no goods or commodities were ever supplied and the money was not repaid 
(the “ Unreturned Prepayments ”). 
e. D1 and D2 together and/or between them were the ultimate beneficiaries of the  
alleged misappropriation of the Bank's funds. 
 
4. The Bank's case is that the misappropriation was disguised by the grant of sham security 
for the Relevant Loans, including sham pledges over shares in companies owned by D1 
and D2 (the value of such shares being vastly inflated) and sham pledges over the 
Borrowers’ unsecured rights under the Relevant Supply Agreements.  
 
5. The Bank contends that the Relevant Loans not been the subject of legitimate repayment 
and the principal sum of its loss  is c. US$1.9 billion. 
 
6. In response to the allegations, as to D1: 
a. D1 denies that he owned or controlled the Borrowers or any of D3-8, although 
he admits having an interest in 21 of the Borrowers;  
b. D1 denies that he controlled material decisions made by the Bank; 
c. D1 denies that he caused the Relevant Loans to be made by the Bank. 
d. D1 denies that he caused the Relevant Supply Agreements to be entered into 
by the Borrowers and D3-8;

7. As to D2:  
 
a. D2 denies that he owned or controlled the Borrowers or any of D3-8, although he 
admits to having an interest in 19  of the Borrowers;  
 
b. D2 denies that he controlled the Bank. He denies that he controlled material 
decisions of the Bank and says that, although he was a member of the Bank’s 
Supervisory Board, management of the Bank was the responsibility of its 
Management Board.   
 
c. D2 denies that he caused the Relevant Loans to be made by the Bank. D2 does 
not believe that the Relevant Loans were referred to the Supervisory Board for 
approval.  
 
d. D2 denies that he caused the Relevant Supply Agreements to be entered into by 
the Borrowers and D3-8. 
 
e. D2 denies that he was aware of the making of the Relevant Loans or the Relevant 
Supply Agreements at the relevant time. D2 says that, if the Borrowers and D3-8 
did enter into the various agreements alleged by the Bank, it was not with his 
knowledge or on his instructions. 
 
f. D2 denies that the making of the Relevant Loans to the Borrowers, or the transfer 
of money by the Borrowers to D3-8, involved any misappropriation of the Bank's 
funds. 
 
8. D3-8 deny that they were owned or controlled by D1 or D2, deny that they were party to 
any misappropriation and deny that their alleged acts (even if proved) caused loss:  
 
a. D3-D5 contend that they entered into the Relevant Supply Agreements (and other 
documents) as agents for undisclosed principals (the “ Alleged Principals ”); they 
did not seek to verify the substance of the transactions; they had no knowledge of 
the commercial purpose of their Alleged Principals’ entry into the transactions; they 
AA1/2/3
 
   
 executed the agreements in good faith; and any sums they received they paid on 
immediately on their Alleged Principal’s instructions to their Alleged Principals or 
to third parties identified by their Alleged Principals. D3-D5 deny any liability to the 
Bank. 
 
b. D6-D8 contend that the Relevant Supply Agreements entered into by them were 
genuine, arm’s length agreements. They made onward payments of the sums 
received before having any notice of the Bank’s claim. They accept that they did 
not supply any goods under those agreements and therefore became (and remain) 
obliged to pay the counter-party Borrowers the amounts of the prepayments 
received from them.  They too deny liability to the Bank. 
 
c. D3–D8 deny that their execution of agreements or the transfers of payments in and 
out of their accounts caused the Bank loss.  D3–D8 adopt the contentions of D1 
(at paragraph 10 below) that the Bank suffered no loss.  They put the Bank to proof 
that any proved loss would not have been suffered but for the alleged acts of D3–
D8. 
 
9. D1 and D2 further contend that the Bank has suffered no loss, or at least no loss caused 
by D1 and D2. In particular, D1 and/or D2 contend that: 
 
a. The Relevant Loans have been the subject of legitimate repayment, including by 
cash repayments (“the Cash Repayments ”, comprising repayments funded by 
drawdowns on loans entered into by 34 further borrowers (the “ Intermediary 
Loans ” and the “ Intermediary Borrowers ”)) and a transfer of assets to the Bank 
(“the Asset Transfer ”) to reduce the sums outstanding in respect of the Relevant 
Loans.  Further, the Bank made a series of new loans totalling approximately 
US$5.7 billion to 36 companies in October-November 2016 (the “ New Loans ” and 
the “New Borrowers ”). The New Borrowers used those funds to repay old loans 
including sums outstanding under the Relevant Loans and the Intermediary Loans. 
This process is referred to as the “ Transformation ”. 
 
b. Any loss the Bank has suffered was caused either by: (

nsfer ”) to reduce the sums outstanding in respect of the Relevant 
Loans.  Further, the Bank made a series of new loans totalling approximately 
US$5.7 billion to 36 companies in October-November 2016 (the “ New Loans ” and 
the “New Borrowers ”). The New Borrowers used those funds to repay old loans 
including sums outstanding under the Relevant Loans and the Intermediary Loans. 
This process is referred to as the “ Transformation ”. 
 
b. Any loss the Bank has suffered was caused either by: ( i) the Bank itself in 
conducting the Transformation under the orders of the NBU; or ( ii) otherwise by the 
NBU as the old loans had been adequately secured by collateral including share 
pledges (“the Share Pledges ”) but this security was released before the assets 
owned by the companies whose shares had been pledged could be used to secure 
the New Loans.   
AA1/2/4
 
   
  
c. In any event, at least a large proportion of the monies drawn down under the 
Relevant Loans were ultimately transferred back to the Bank either to repay sums 
due under the Relevant Loans or some other debts owed to the Bank by the same 
or different borrowers. 
 
10. The Bank denies that the Relevant Loans have been the subject of valid repayments. It 
contends that the Intermediary Loans, which funded the Cash Repayments, were simply a 
further layer of sham lending to companies owned or controlled by D1 and/or D2 and did 
not constitute a genuine source of recovery for the Bank and did not reduce its loss. The 
Bank admits that it obtained ownership and control of certain assets identified as part of 
the Asset Transfer and accepts that the value of its claim will be reduced by the “true” value 
of those assets with certain limited exceptions to the extent that those assets can be shown 
to have been applied to reduce the balances under the Relevant Drawdowns. The Bank 
contends that the purported values of the assets pledged to the Bank were significantly 
and deliberately inflated by D1-2. It also contends that the New Loans were designed to 
disguise earlier illegitimate lending and denies that the Share Pledges were adequate or 
valuable security for the old loans.  
11. D1-D8 also contend that the Bank’s claims are barred by the three year limitation period 
applicable in Ukrainian law. The Bank’s case is that this period did not start to run whilst 
D1 and D2 remained in ownership of the Bank or that the limitation period should be 
disapplied. 
12. The Bank brings claims in tort against D1-D8 and in unjust enrichment against D3-D8.  
13. It is common ground that the Bank’s tort claims are governed by Ukrainian law. The Bank’s 
claims in unjust enrichment are governed by Ukrainian law or (on D3-D8s’ case) Cypriot 
law. In denying those claims, D3–D8 rely, inter alia, on contentions that: the causes of 
action relied upon are not engaged given the ‘indirect’ nature of the alleged enrichment; 
the transfers were pursuant to (at least then) valid contracts, involved monies of the 
Borrowers (not the Bank), the credit balances in D3–D5s’ accounts were held for their 
Alleged Principals, D3–D8 had no notice of the Bank’s claims before making onward 
transfers, and the onward transfers were made very shortly after the inward transfers.  
14. The Bank’s claims in tort include (in respect of D1-D2) claims alleging breach of the 
provisions of the Ukrainian JSC Law and the Law on Banks. In addition to denying fault 
and/or liability by reference to the specific provisions relied on by the Bank, D1-D2 contend 
that, because they had contracts with the Bank as members of its Supervisory Board, the 
Bank cannot sue them in tort.  Alternatively, D1-D2 contend that  the substance of the
